para.para.body: It is very likely that you have already come in contact with the concept of a function. For example, within the context of calculus, you might have gotten used thinking of a function as a curve in a 2D-coordinate system like this one:
Here the domain X of the function is an interval of the horizontal axis, and the target Y is \RNr . The curve in the graphic consists of all points (x,y) in \RNr[2] with x in X and y=f(x) .
Let us understand clearly that the curve in the graphic does not depict the transformation described by f . Rather, the curve is called the ‘graph’ of f .

For most of our present purposes the graph is not the appropriate object to associate to a function. Therefore it is necessary to take the concept of a function in its original form and then learn how to use it to transforms space.
